SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Direct invasive monitoring of brain tissue oxygenation (PbtO(2)) has been routinely utilized to predict cerebral ischemia and to prevent secondary injury in patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI) and vasospasm secondary to subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)
The safety and utility of these devices in the pediatric population have been examined in a few small studies
No studies, however, have examined the use of PbtO(2) monitoring in stroke patients

METHODS: Retrospective chart review of the first two consecutive, critically ill pediatric patients in the pediatric intensive care unit requiring brain tissue oxygen monitoring for newly diagnosed cerebral ischemia
ICP, CPP, PbtO(2), SaO(2), BP, and RR were all continually monitored during their care and were retrospectively collected and reviewed
RESULTS: We present two pediatric stroke patients managed in a critical care setting with PbtO(2) monitoring in addition to ICP, MAP, CPP, and SaO(2)
Both patients had multiple events of low brain tissue oxygen (PbtO(2) <20Â torr), independent of abnormal values in other monitoring parameters, which required physician intervention
No new ischemic damage occurred after PbtO(2) monitoring began in either patient
CONCLUSIONS: There is currently inadequate data to support the application of PbtO(2) monitoring in children with stroke to prevent progressive ischemia and to improve outcome
However, the positive results for these two patients support the need for further study in this area
